ruleset.name: Default ruleset used by the CodeClimate Engine for Salesforce.com Apex
ruleset.description: Ruleset used for Apex Code in Genesis

rule.message: Apex unit tests should System.assert() or assertEquals() or assertNotEquals()
rule.description: Apex unit tests should include at least one assertion. This makes the tests more robust, and using assert with messages provide the developer a clearer idea of what the test does.

rule.name: ApexUnitTestShouldNotUseSeeAllDataTrue
rule.message: Apex unit tests should not use @isTest(seeAllData = true)
rule.description: Apex unit tests should not use @isTest(seeAllData=true) because it opens up the existing database data for unexpected modification by tests.

rule.name: AvoidGlobalModifier
rule.message: Avoid using global modifier
rule.description: Global classes should be avoided (especially in managed packages) as they can never be deleted or changed in signature. Always check twice if something needs to be global. Many interfaces (e.g. Batch) required global modifiers in the past but don't require this anymore. Don't lock yourself in.

rule.name: AvoidLogicInTrigger
rule.message: Avoid logic in triggers
rule.description:
As triggers do not allow methods like regular classes they are less flexible and suited to apply good encapsulation style. Therefore delegate the triggers work to a regular class (often called Trigger handler class).
See more here: https://developer.salesforce.com/page/Trigger_Frameworks_and_Apex_Trigger_Best_Practices

rule.name: ClassNamingConventions
rule.message: Class names should begin with an uppercase character
rule.description: Class names should always begin with an upper case character.
rule.example: public class Foo {}

rule.name: ForLoopsMustUseBraces
rule.message: Avoid using 'for' statements without curly braces
rule.description: Avoid using 'for' statements without using surrounding braces. If the code formatting or indentation is lost then it becomes difficult to separate the code being controlled from the rest.

rule.name: IfElseStmtsMustUseBraces
rule.message: Avoid using 'if...else' statements without curly braces
rule.description: Avoid using if..else statements without using surrounding braces. If the code formatting or indentation is lost then it becomes difficult to separate the code being controlled from the rest.

rule.name: IfStmtsMustUseBraces
rule.message: Avoid using if statements without curly braces
rule.description: Avoid using if statements without using braces to surround the code block. If the code formatting or indentation is lost then it becomes difficult to separate the code being controlled from the rest.

rule.name: MethodNamingConventions
rule.message: Method name does not begin with a lower case character.
rule.description: Method names should always begin with a lower case character, and should not contain underscores.

rule.name: OneDeclarationPerLine
rule.message: Use one statement for each line, it enhances code readability.
rule.description: Apex allows the use of several variables declaration of the same type on one line. However, it can lead to quite messy code. This rule looks for several declarations on the same line.

property.name: strictMode
property.description: If true, mark combined declaration even if the declarations are on separate lines.

rule.example: Integer a, b; // not recommended Integer a, b; // ok by default, can be flagged setting the strictMode property Integer a; // preferred approach Integer b;

rule.name: VariableNamingConventions
rule.message: {0} variable {1} should begin with {2}
rule.description: A variable naming conventions rule - customize this to your liking. Currently, it checks for final variables that should be fully capitalized and non-final variables that should not include underscores.

rule.name: WhileLoopsMustUseBraces
rule.message: Avoid using 'while' statements without curly braces
rule.description: Avoid using 'while' statements without using braces to surround the code block. If the code formatting or indentation is lost then it becomes difficult to separate the code being controlled from the rest.

rule.name: AvoidDeeplyNestedIfStmts
rule.message: Deeply nested if..then statements are hard to read
rule.description: Avoid creating deeply nested if-then statements since they are harder to read and error-prone to maintain.

rule.name: CyclomaticComplexity
rule.message: The {0} ''{1}'' has a{2} cyclomatic complexity of {3}.
rule.description:
The complexity of methods directly affects maintenance costs and readability. Concentrating too much decisional logic in a single method makes its behaviour hard to read and change.
Cyclomatic complexity assesses the complexity of a method by counting the number of decision points in a method, plus one for the method entry. Decision points are places where the control flow jumps to another place in the program. As such, they include all control flow statements, such as 'if', 'while', 'for', and 'case'.
Generally, numbers ranging from 1-4 denote low complexity, 5-7 denote moderate complexity, 8-10 denote high complexity, and 11+ is very high complexity. By default, this rule reports methods with a complexity >= 10. Additionnally, classes with many methods of moderate complexity get reported as well once the total of their methods' complexities reaches 40, even if none of the methods was directly reported.
Reported methods should be broken down into several smaller methods. Reported classes should probably be broken down into subcomponents.

rule.name: ExcessiveClassLength
rule.message: Avoid really long classes.
rule.description: Excessive class file lengths are usually indications that the class may be burdened with excessive responsibilities that could be provided by external classes or functions. In breaking these methods apart the code becomes more managable and ripe for reuse.

rule.name: ExcessiveParameterList
rule.message: Avoid long parameter lists.
rule.description: Methods with numerous parameters are a challenge to maintain, especially if most of them share the same datatype. These situations usually denote the need for new objects to wrap the numerous parameters.

rule.name: ExcessivePublicCount
rule.message: This class has a bunch of public methods and attributes
rule.description: Classes with large numbers of public methods and attributes require disproportionate testing efforts since combinational side effects grow rapidly and increase risk. Refactoring these classes into smaller ones not only increases testability and reliability but also allows new variations to be developed easily.

rule.name: NcssConstructorCount
rule.message: The constructor has an NCSS line count of {0}
rule.description: This rule uses the NCSS (Non-Commenting Source Statements) algorithm to determine the number of lines of code for a given constructor. NCSS ignores comments, and counts actual statements. Using this algorithm, lines of code that are split are counted as one.

rule.name: NcssMethodCount
rule.message: The method ''{0}()'' has an NCSS line count of {1}
rule.description: This rule uses the NCSS (Non-Commenting Source Statements) algorithm to determine the number of lines of code for a given method. NCSS ignores comments, and counts actual statements. Using this algorithm, lines of code that are split are counted as one.

rule.name: NcssTypeCount
rule.message: The type has an NCSS line count of {0}
rule.description: This rule uses the NCSS (Non-Commenting Source Statements) algorithm to determine the number of lines of code for a given type. NCSS ignores comments, and counts actual statements. Using this algorithm, lines of code that are split are counted as one.

rule.name: StdCyclomaticComplexity
rule.message: The {0} ''{1}'' has a Standard Cyclomatic Complexity of {2}.
rule.description: Complexity directly affects maintenance costs is determined by the number of decision points in a method plus one for the method entry. The decision points include 'if', 'while', 'for', and 'case labels' calls. Generally, numbers ranging from 1-4 denote low complexity, 5-7 denote moderate complexity, 8-10 denote high complexity, and 11+ is very high complexity.

rule.name: TooManyFields
rule.message: Too many fields
rule.description: Classes that have too many fields can become unwieldy and could be redesigned to have fewer fields, possibly through grouping related fields in new objects. For example, a class with individual city/state/zip fields could park them within a single Address field.

rule.name: ApexDoc
rule.message: ApexDoc comment is missing or incorrect
rule.description:
This rule validates that:
* ApexDoc comments are present for classes, methods, and properties that are public or global, excluding overrides and test classes (as well as the contents of test classes). * ApexDoc comments should contain @description. * ApexDoc comments on non-void, non-constructor methods should contain @return. * ApexDoc comments on void or constructor methods should not contain @return. * ApexDoc comments on methods with parameters should contain @param for each parameter, in the same order as the method signature.
Method overrides and tests are both exempted from having ApexDoc.

rule.name: AvoidDirectAccessTriggerMap
rule.message: Avoid directly accessing Trigger.old and Trigger.new
rule.description: Avoid directly accessing Trigger.old and Trigger.new as it can lead to a bug. Triggers should be bulkified and iterate through the map to handle the actions for each item separately.

rule.name: AvoidHardcodingId
rule.message: Hardcoding Id's is bound to break when changing environments.
rule.description: When deploying Apex code between sandbox and production environments, or installing Force.com AppExchange packages, it is essential to avoid hardcoding IDs in the Apex code. By doing so, if the record IDs change between environments, the logic can dynamically identify the proper data to operate against and not fail.

rule.name: AvoidNonExistentAnnotations
rule.message: Use of non existent annotations will lead to broken Apex code which will not compile in the future.
rule.description: Apex supported non existent annotations for legacy reasons. In the future, use of such non-existent annotations could result in broken apex code that will not compile. This will prevent users of garbage annotations from being able to use legitimate annotations added to Apex in the future. A full list of supported annotations can be found at https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.apexcode.meta/apexcode/apex_classes_annotation.htm

rule.name: EmptyCatchBlock
rule.message: Avoid empty catch blocks
rule.description: Empty Catch Block finds instances where an exception is caught, but nothing is done. In most circumstances, this swallows an exception which should either be acted on or reported.

rule.name: EmptyIfStmt
rule.message: Avoid empty 'if' statements
rule.description: Empty If Statement finds instances where a condition is checked but nothing is done about it.

rule.name: EmptyStatementBlock
rule.message: Avoid empty block statements.
rule.description: Empty block statements serve no purpose and should be removed.

rule.name: EmptyTryOrFinallyBlock
rule.message: Avoid empty try or finally blocks
rule.description: Avoid empty try or finally blocks - what's the point?

rule.name: EmptyWhileStmt
rule.message: Avoid empty 'while' statements
rule.description: Empty While Statement finds all instances where a while statement does nothing. If it is a timing loop, then you should use Thread.sleep() for it; if it is a while loop that does a lot in the exit expression, rewrite it to make it clearer.

rule.name: MethodWithSameNameAsEnclosingClass
rule.message: Classes should not have non-constructor methods with the same name as the class
rule.description: Non-constructor methods should not have the same name as the enclosing class.

rule.name: AvoidDmlStatementsInLoops
rule.message: Avoid DML statements inside loops
rule.description: Avoid DML statements inside loops to avoid hitting the DML governor limit. Instead, try to batch up the data into a list and invoke your DML once on that list of data outside the loop.

rule.name: AvoidSoqlInLoops
rule.message: Avoid Soql queries inside loops
rule.description: New objects created within loops should be checked to see if they can created outside them and reused.

rule.name: AvoidSoslInLoops
rule.message: Avoid Sosl queries inside loops
rule.description: Sosl calls within loops can cause governor limit exceptions.

rule.name: ApexBadCrypto
rule.message: Apex classes should use random IV/key
rule.description: The rule makes sure you are using randomly generated IVs and keys for `Crypto` calls. Hard-wiring these values greatly compromises the security of encrypted data.

rule.name: ApexCRUDViolation
rule.message: Validate CRUD permission before SOQL/DML operation
rule.description: The rule validates you are checking for access permissions before a SOQL/SOSL/DML operation. Since Apex runs in system mode not having proper permissions checks results in escalation of privilege and may produce runtime errors. This check forces you to handle such scenarios.

rule.name: ApexCSRF
rule.message: Avoid making DML operations in Apex class constructor/init method
rule.description: Check to avoid making DML operations in Apex class constructor/init method. This prevents modification of the database just by accessing a page.

rule.name: ApexDangerousMethods
rule.message: Calling potentially dangerous method
rule.description:
Checks against calling dangerous methods.
For the time being, it reports:
* Against `FinancialForce`'s `Configuration.disableTriggerCRUDSecurity()`. Disabling CRUD security opens the door to several attacks and requires manual validation, which is unreliable. * Calling `System.debug` passing sensitive data as parameter, which could lead to exposure of private data.

rule.name: ApexInsecureEndpoint
rule.message: Apex callouts should use encrypted communication channels
rule.description: Checks against accessing endpoints under plain **http**. You should always use **https** for security.

rule.name: ApexOpenRedirect
rule.message: Apex classes should safely redirect to a known location
rule.description: Checks against redirects to user-controlled locations. This prevents attackers from redirecting users to phishing sites.

rule.name: ApexSharingViolations
rule.message: Apex classes should declare a sharing model if DML or SOQL/SOSL is used
rule.description: Detect classes declared without explicit sharing mode if DML methods are used. This forces the developer to take access restrictions into account before modifying objects.

rule.name: ApexSOQLInjection
rule.message: Avoid untrusted/unescaped variables in DML query
rule.description: Detects the usage of untrusted / unescaped variables in DML queries.

rule.name: ApexSuggestUsingNamedCred
rule.message: Suggest named credentials for authentication
rule.description:
Detects hardcoded credentials used in requests to an endpoint.
You should refrain from hardcoding credentials: * They are hard to mantain by being mixed in application code * Particularly hard to update them when used from different classes * Granting a developer access to the codebase means granting knowledge of credentials, keeping a two-level access is not possible. * Using different credentials for different environments is troublesome and error-prone.
Instead, you should use *Named Credentials* and a callout endpoint.
For more information, you can check [this](https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.apexcode.meta/apexcode/apex_callouts_named_credentials.htm)

rule.name: ApexXSSFromEscapeFalse
rule.message: Apex classes should escape Strings in error messages
rule.description: Reports on calls to `addError` with disabled escaping. The message passed to `addError` will be displayed directly to the user in the UI, making it prime ground for XSS attacks if unescaped.

rule.name: ApexXSSFromURLParam
rule.message: Apex classes should escape/sanitize Strings obtained from URL parameters
rule.description: Makes sure that all values obtained from URL parameters are properly escaped / sanitized to avoid XSS attacks.

rule.name: VfCsrf
rule.message: Avoid calling VF action upon page load
rule.description: Avoid calling VF action upon page load as the action becomes vulnerable to CSRF.
rule.example: <apex:page controller="AcRestActionsController" action="{!csrfInitMethod}" >

rule.name: VfUnescapeEl
rule.message: Avoid unescaped user controlled content in EL
rule.description: Avoid unescaped user controlled content in EL as it results in XSS.
rule.example: <apex:outputText value="Potential XSS is {! here }" escape="false" />

rule.name: AvoidWithStatement
rule.message: Avoid using with - it's bad news
rule.description: Avoid using with - it's bad news

rule.name: ConsistentReturn
rule.message: A function should not mix 'return' statements with and without a result.
rule.description: ECMAScript does provide for return types on functions, and therefore there is no solid rule as to their usage. However, when a function does use returns they should all have a value, or all with no value. Mixed return usage is likely a bug, or at best poor style.

rule.name: GlobalVariable
rule.message: Avoid using global variables
rule.description: This rule helps to avoid using accidently global variables by simply missing the "var" declaration. Global variables can lead to side-effects that are hard to debug.

rule.name: ScopeForInVariable
rule.message: The for-in loop variable ''{0}'' should be explicitly scoped with 'var' to avoid pollution.
rule.description: A for-in loop in which the variable name is not explicitly scoped to the enclosing scope with the 'var' keyword can refer to a variable in an enclosing scope outside the nearest enclosing scope. This will overwrite the existing value of the variable in the outer scope when the body of the for-in is evaluated. When the for-in loop has finished, the variable will contain the last value used in the for-in, and the original value from before the for-in loop will be gone. Since the for-in variable name is most likely intended to be a temporary name, it is better to explicitly scope the variable name to the nearest enclosing scope with 'var'.

rule.name: UseBaseWithParseInt
rule.message: Always provide a base when using parseInt() functions
rule.description:
This rule checks for usages of parseInt. While the second parameter is optional and usually defaults to 10 (base/radix is 10 for a decimal number), different implementations may behave differently. It also improves readability, if the base is given.
See also: [parseInt()](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/parseInt)
rule.example: parseInt("010"); // unclear, could be interpreted as 10 or 7 (with a base of 7) parseInt("10", 10); // good

rule.name: AssignmentInOperand
rule.message: Avoid assignments in operands
rule.description: Avoid assignments in operands; this can make code more complicated and harder to read. This is sometime indicative of the bug where the assignment operator '=' was used instead of the equality operator '=='.

property.name: xpath
allowIf
property.description: Allow assignment within the conditional expression of an if statement

property.name: allowFor
property.description: Allow assignment within the conditional expression of a for statement

property.name: allowWhile
property.description: Allow assignment within the conditional expression of a while statement

property.name: allowTernary
property.description: Allow assignment within the conditional expression of a ternary operator

property.name: allowTernaryResults
property.description: Allow assignment within the result expressions of a ternary operator

property.name: allowIncrementDecrement
property.description: Allow increment or decrement operators within the conditional expression of an if, for, or while statement

rule.name: ForLoopsMustUseBraces
rule.message: Avoid using 'for' statements without curly braces
rule.description: Avoid using 'for' statements without using curly braces.

rule.name: IfElseStmtsMustUseBraces
rule.message: Avoid using 'if...else' statements without curly braces
rule.description: Avoid using if..else statements without using curly braces.

rule.name: IfStmtsMustUseBraces
rule.message: Avoid using if statements without curly braces
rule.description: Avoid using if statements without using curly braces.

rule.name: NoElseReturn
rule.message: The else block is unnecessary
rule.description:
The else block in a if-else-construct is unnecessary if the `if` block contains a return. Then the content of the else block can be put outside.
See also: <http://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-else-return>

rule.name: UnnecessaryBlock
rule.message: Unnecessary block.
rule.description: An unnecessary Block is present. Such Blocks are often used in other languages to introduce a new variable scope. Blocks do not behave like this in ECMAScipt, and using them can be misleading. Considering removing this unnecessary Block.

property.name: xpath

rule.name: UnnecessaryParentheses
rule.message: Unnecessary parentheses.
rule.description: Unnecessary parentheses should be removed.
rule.example: var x = 1; // Ok var y = (1 + 1); // Ok var z = ((1 + 1)); // Bad

rule.name: UnreachableCode
rule.message: A ''return'', ''break'', ''continue'', or ''throw'' statement should be the last in a block.
rule.description: A 'return', 'break', 'continue', or 'throw' statement should be the last in a block. Statements after these will never execute. This is a bug, or extremely poor style.

rule.name: WhileLoopsMustUseBraces
rule.message: Avoid using 'while' statements without curly braces
rule.description: Avoid using 'while' statements without using curly braces.

rule.name: AvoidTrailingComma
rule.message: Avoid trailing commas in object or array literals
rule.description: This rule helps improve code portability due to differences in browser treatment of trailing commas in object or array literals.

property.name: xpath
allowObjectLiteral
property.description: Allow a trailing comma within an object literal

property.name: allowArrayLiteral
property.description: Allow a trailing comma within an array literal

rule.name: EqualComparison
rule.message: Use '==='/'!==' to compare with true/false or Numbers
rule.description: Using == in condition may lead to unexpected results, as the variables are automatically casted to be of the same type. The === operator avoids the casting.

rule.name: InnaccurateNumericLiteral
rule.message: The numeric literal ''{0}'' will have at different value at runtime.
rule.description: The numeric literal will have a different value at runtime, which can happen if you provide too much precision in a floating point number. This may result in numeric calculations being in error.
